In this work, we report the structure of neon hydrate at high pressure and temperature. The results provide a reference for the structure of hydrate under high pressure and temperature. This work also provides a new method for the synthesis of hydrate. The method is simple, and the structure of hydrate can be controlled by changing the composition of the guest. The foundations of quantum mechanics are a major open problem in science. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical approach to the foundations of quantum mechanics. Our approach is based on the observation that the category of Hilbert spaces and bounded linear operators is equivalent to the category of continuous linear functions on the category of metric spaces and continuous functions. This equivalence provides a categorical foundation for quantum mechanics.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that are of great interest to both basic and applied science. Although the evolutionary origin of myxozoans has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we present a comparison of the transcriptomes and genomes of two distantly related myxozoan species to the transcriptome and genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. These results have implications for understanding the origin of the Myxozoa and the evolution of parasitic lifestyles. (Show more)

The ability of the immune system to recognize and eliminate pathogens is a key factor in the survival of the host. In the case of viruses, the immune system can be used by the pathogen to its advantage, as it is the case of the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic. In this study, we describe a mechanism by which the SARS-CoV-2 virus is able to block the nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are essential for the induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). Our results show that the SARS-CoV-2 accessory protein Orf6 is able to bind to the Nup98-Rae1 complex, which is involved in the nuclear import of STAT1 and STAT2, and to impair the docking of the cargo-receptor complex. This mechanism represents a new strategy used by the virus to antagonize the antiviral action of IFN. (Show more)

The proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1, but the molecular mechanism of this inhibition is not completely understood. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. Climate change will affect the productivity of the world’s major crops, but the magnitude of the effects is difficult to predict because of the complexity of the processes involved. Here, we use a global dataset of maize production and climate variability to quantify how yield variability will change in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. We find that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase almost everywhere to values much larger than present-day values. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation of yields and a decrease in mean yields. Our results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes.

The extent to which different species of large mammalian herbivores (LMH) partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level differences in food consumption. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant LMH species (six wild, one domestic) in semiarid African savanna. Our results show that, despite being similar in size and digestive physiology, LMH consumed different plant species, and that the proportion of plant species consumed was different between species. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results also suggest that the use of DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap may be a powerful tool for understanding the ecology of LMH.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off or closed, and that the length of the crisis is negatively associated with the expected duration of business closures. However, many businesses are financially fragile, and the majority plan to seek funding through the CARES Act.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible consequences of human activities in the ocean. However, the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is far less than expected, and that the missing plastic debris is mostly concentrated in the convergence zones of the five subtropical gyres. This distribution is consistent with the accumulation of plastic debris on the surface of the open ocean, but the magnitude of the load is far less than expected. This discrepancy is likely due to the size-selective nature of the sinks of floating plastic debris, which are mostly responsible for the removal of the millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic.

The origin of presolar silicon carbide grains is still a matter of debate. We determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. We found that a majority of the grains have ages of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. We also found that at least 12 of the analyzed grains were parts of aggregates in the interstellar medium. The grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. Our results provide evidence for a longer lifetime of large grains in the interstellar medium.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the number of motorized vessels has increased exponentially. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is the defining characteristic of all life on Earth. In this study, we show that the ability to reproduce is also the most limiting factor in the evolution of placental mammals. We show that the ability to reproduce is strongly correlated with the amount of energy available to the mother. This energy is not only available to the mother, but it is also used to increase the size of the litter.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes. The aim of this study was to evaluate the efficacy of the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 in a mouse model of MSA. We show that VX-765, when administered in a 11-wk-long study, was able to limit the progressive toxicity of α-syn aggregation in a dose-dependent manner. More importantly, VX-765 was able to reduce the load of truncated α-syn, as well as its monomeric and oligomeric forms. Finally, VX-765 showed neuroprotective effects by preserving tyrosine hydroxylase-positive neurons in the substantia nigra. In conclusion, our results suggest that VX-765, a drug that was well tolerated in a 6 wk-long phase II trial in patients with epilepsy, is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This study provides an in vivo proof of concept for the potential of VX-765 to be developed as a therapeutic agent

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the interface between the circulatory system and the tissues of the body. It is the most abundant cell type in the body and is responsible for a wide variety of functions, including control of blood pressure, regulation of inflammation, and control of blood flow. The endothelium is a highly specialized cell type that is able to respond to a wide variety of stimuli. The endothelium is able to communicate with other cells in the body, and this communication is critical for the proper functioning of the body.

The COVID-19 pandemic has presented enormous data challenges. We describe the design and implementation of the COVIDcast API, a data source that provides open access to many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity, including signals extracted from deidentified medical claims data, massive online surveys, cell phone mobility data, and internet search trends. These are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. We provide examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making. We hope that the COVIDcast API will be useful to researchers, health policymakers, and the general public.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. This allosteric coupling underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We have shown that a Threonine to Alanine substitution at this position is responsible for the loss of C-type inactivation gating and the inversion of the allosteric coupling (i.e., closing of the activation gate collapses the channel’s selectivity filter). Finally, we have provided a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter. This work provides a structural basis for the functional coupling of the activation gate and the selectivity filter in potassium channels. It also provides a structural basis for the functional inversion of the allosteric coupling in the same ion-channel family. View Full-Text

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to be important for the health of the host. However, the natural products that are produced by the gut microbiome are not well characterized. Here, we show that anaerobic fungi in the gut microbiome of herbivores produce a variety of natural products, including antibiotics, antimicrobials, and other bioactive compounds. This is the first report of the production of natural products by anaerobic fungi.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality in the establishment of social hierarchy remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that is associated with a high risk of becoming subordinate, directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats. We further identify a key role for brain energy metabolism in the nucleus accumbens, a brain region involved in social behavior, in the establishment of social hierarchy. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This work provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of personality in social behavior and may lead to the development of new therapeutic approaches for social disorders. The design of mechanical structures with programmable responses is of great importance for various applications. However, the current design approaches are limited by the availability of materials and the complexity of the structures. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy of composite structures with multiple materials and demonstrate the design of programmable structures with complex shapes and functions. The proposed strategy can be extended to the design of structures with more materials and functions. The developed structures can be manufactured by multimaterial fabrication, which is a promising approach for the mass production of programmable structures. The proposed strategy and the developed structures can be used to design various mechanical devices with programmable responses for a wide range of applications. This work will promote the development of programmable structures and their applications.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-carrying protein of red blood cells. The hemoglobin gene expression pattern is a critical determinant of the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood. In this study, we show that the IGF2BP1 protein, which is expressed in the erythroid lineage, is a key regulator of the hemoglobin expression pattern. We show that IGF2BP1 is down-regulated in the fetal erythroid lineage and that its overexpression in the erythroid lineage results in a reversal of the adult hemoglobin expression pattern. This reversal is mediated by a reduction in the expression of the transcription factor BCL11A, which is required for the expression of fetal hemoglobin. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. (Show more)

Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation, in cancer cells. This resistance is mediated by activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis, which, in turn, promotes lipogenesis through the SREBP1/SCD1 pathway. We also found that inhibition of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway sensitizes cancer cells to ferroptosis induction in vitro and in vivo. These findings provide a rationale for the combination of ferroptosis induction with PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway inhibition in cancer therapy. (Show more)

Hypertension is the most common cardiovascular disease, and the treatment of hypertension is the most important strategy to prevent cardiovascular disease. However, the treatment of hypertension is often associated with the development of cardiovascular complications. The most common treatment for hypertension is the use of drugs that block the action of the L-type Ca2+ channel. However, the use of these drugs is associated with the development of cardiovascular complications. Our study shows that the use of these drugs is associated with the development of cardiovascular complications.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed forest management on 10 million hectares of federal land. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of bird populations associated with early-seral forests, but not older forests. We also show that the NWFP failed to halt the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations, despite the fact that the policy halted clearcutting on federal land. Our results highlight the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and the need to ensure that the creation of early-seral forests does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge, and computational approaches are essential tools to this end. In this study, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. The best candidate is synthetically more accessible, exhibits higher solubility and binding affinity to the ribosome, and is up to 56 times more active against resistant pathogens than telithromycin. Notably, the best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The results of this study provide a proof of concept for the rational design of new antibiotics. This approach can be extended to other classes of antibiotics and to other targets. The results of this study may contribute to the development of new antibiotics.

Deep learning has been shown to be a powerful tool for image processing. However, the number of trainable parameters in deep networks can be very large, which can make training and applying the network difficult. We introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and that is easy to implement and train. We show that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters than popular existing architectures, and that it is easier to train and apply. The proposed architecture is also able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters than other popular architectures, and is easier to implement and train. We believe that the proposed architecture will be useful for many applications of deep learning.

The evolution of the Lake Malawi cichlid fish species flock is a classic example of the effects of environmental change on biological evolution. The species flock is a group of closely related cichlid fish endemic to Lake Malawi, which has undergone dramatic changes in hydroclimate over the past 1.3 My. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind record of the hydroclimate of the region, derived from a drill core from Lake Malawi. Our results show that the evolution of the species flock was influenced by the changing hydroclimate of the region.

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is a growing phenomenon in the United States and around the world. This study shows that the use of an electronic device in the hours before bedtime has important effects on sleep, including a delayed circadian clock, reduced melatonin levels, and reduced alertness the next morning. These effects may have important implications for health, safety, and performance.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known event in the Holocene, but the cause of this cooling is still a matter of debate. One of the most widely accepted hypotheses is that one or more bolide impacts triggered the cooling. However, the evidence for such impacts is not conclusive. We show that the osmium isotope composition of the sediments and magnetic grains/microspherules from the YDB sites in the United States are consistent with a terrestrial origin, and the spherules from the YDB in Pennsylvania are consistent with their origin from a meteorite impact. These results support the hypothesis that meteorite impacts triggered the Younger Dryas cooling. (Show more)

The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its function in the development of autoimmunity is not yet fully understood. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity, but its function is not limited to the control of T cell activation.

Beetles are the most speciose group of animals, but the origin of this diversity remains poorly understood. We show that the evolution of beetles is linked to the origin of plant cell wall-degrading enzymes, which enabled the evolution of specialized plant-feeding habits.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our work has the potential to accelerate the development of new therapeutics to combat the COVID-19 pandemic.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report the results of a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We found that larger populations did not enhance CCE, but that the size of the population was more important than the number of models in the population.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE is a protein that is involved in lipid metabolism and is also a major component of senescent synapses in the brain. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of senescent synapses, which is highly dependent on APOE isoform. We also found that APOE alleles influence the rate of C1q accumulation in the brain, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere that is 1,220 km in diameter and has a density of 12.0 g/cm3. It is the only solid sphere in the universe. The inner core is a mystery because it is not understood how it formed. This paper provides a solution to the mystery.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the brain mechanisms of marijuana abuse are not fully understood, the present study provides evidence that the brain DA system is dysregulated in marijuana abusers, which may contribute to their negative emotionality and addictive behaviors.

Language is a uniquely human skill, and the brain’s processing of it is a central focus of neuroscience. However, the brain’s mechanisms for language comprehension are not understood. Here, we show that a class of deep learning models, trained on large datasets of natural speech, can predict the next word in a sentence with human-level accuracy. We then show that these models’ brain activity during language comprehension can also predict their accuracy on the next-word prediction task. These results provide computational evidence for a fundamental role of predictive processing in the brain’s language comprehension mechanisms.

Deep learning has been a major breakthrough in machine learning, but it is not always stable. We show that this instability is a consequence of the fact that the algorithms used to train deep networks are not stable themselves. We introduce a new class of algorithms that are stable and prove that they are sufficient for the existence of stable algorithms. Our results have implications for the design of stable deep learning algorithms and for the theory of stability in inverse problems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including the failure of governments to act quickly enough, the failure of the pharmaceutical industry to develop a vaccine quickly enough, and the failure of the public to comply with the necessary restrictions. One of the most prominent arguments for the latter failure is that people are unable to understand exponential growth. This argument is based on a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago. We show that the experiment’s critical design flaws were not only overlooked at the time but also, in hindsight, undermine the study’s conclusion.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years. It is caused by two bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae, which causes the disease in the peripheral nervous system, and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which causes the disease in the nervous system and skin. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis and compared it with that of M. leprae. We found that the two bacteria are remarkably similar, and that they have retained many of the same functions. This suggests that they are still able to cause disease, and that they have not lost the ability to cause disease.

Entanglement and entropy are the two main resources for quantum information processing. They are also the two main resources for characterizing the state of a quantum system. However, the relation between them is not trivial, and it is still not fully understood. In this work, we show that the dynamics of entanglement in integrable systems is governed by a simple picture, which is based on the quasiparticles of the system. This picture is exact in the scaling limit of long times and large systems, and it is exact in the steady state, which is integrable. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain.

The development of a safe and effective vaccine against COVID-19 is a global priority. Here, we describe the development of a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine, which is the only vaccine currently in clinical development. The vaccine is temperature sensitive in vitro, but grows robustly at the permissive temperature, and is safe and effective in hamsters. This vaccine has the potential to be used in mass vaccination programs.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, with the Black Death (1347–1353) alone causing the deaths of up to 50 million people in Europe. The vector of the disease is still a matter of debate, with the most common assumption being that rats were responsible for the spread of the disease. Here, we show that human ectoparasites, such as fleas, were the primary vector of the disease during the Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries). Our results have important implications for the understanding of the history of plague and the development of control measures.

The evolution of brain size has been a major focus of research in the field of comparative neurobiology. However, the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is not only about brain size but also about the number of neurons in the brain. This study shows that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

The role of TRAP1 in cancer is controversial. Some studies have shown that TRAP1 is a tumor suppressor, whereas others have shown that it is an oncoprotein. We have found that TRAP1 is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that regulates the metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficient cells display enhanced invasiveness, and TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers. These data suggest that TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings.

Actin filaments are the major structural elements of cells, and their disassembly is essential for many cellular processes. The proteins cofilin and ADF/cofilin are the key regulators of actin filament disassembly. However, how they do so is not fully understood. Here, we show that cofilin binds to and severes actin filaments in a mechanical context, which is relevant to cells. We propose a mechanochemical mechanism that explains our results and is consistent with the known structure of the cofilin-actin complex. Our results have implications for our understanding of the role of cofilin in cells and for the design of new drugs.

Fructose, a common sugar found in many foods and beverages, is a weaker appetite suppressant than glucose, a sugar found in many foods and beverages. This study shows that fructose ingestion results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and its relationship to the brain.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a sex-biased and heterogeneous way, suggesting that the settlement of Madagascar was not a single event but rather a series of independent events. Finally, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar. View Full-Text

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others on Facebook. This is a form of emotional contagion, in which the emotions of others influence the emotions of the observer. We also show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others in real-world social networks. This is a form of emotional contagion, in which the emotions of others influence the emotions of the observer. Our results suggest that in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. This work also suggests that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others in real-world social networks.

Messenger RNA (mRNA) is a critical component of the genetic code, directing protein synthesis. However, mRNA can also be modified posttranscriptionally, and there is growing appreciation that these modifications can have a profound impact on mRNA function. In this study, we show that the presence of a single pseudouridine (Ψ) in an mRNA codon can have a significant impact on translation. We also show that the presence of Ψ in coding regions can increase the rate of protein synthesis in human cells. Our work suggests that the presence of Ψ in mRNA can have a significant impact on protein synthesis, and that the ribosome can encounter Ψ in both coding and noncoding regions of mRNA. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. In this study, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, stronger social relationships, and a healthier lifestyle. These associations are robust to a range of sensitivity analyses, and the feeling that life is worthwhile may therefore be a key factor in promoting healthy aging.

The evolution of body size in mammals is a central topic in biology. Aquatic mammals are larger than their terrestrial relatives, but the extent to which this size increase is a consequence of the aquatic environment or a consequence of the terrestrial environment remains unclear. We show that the aquatic environment is driving the evolution of body size in three of the four extant aquatic mammal lineages.

The common cold is one of the most common and economically devastating diseases in the world. The rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold, and the ability of this virus to cause disease is dependent on the ability of the virus to replicate in the nasal cavity. In this study, we show that the temperature at which the virus replicates in the nasal cavity influences the ability of the virus to replicate in the nasal cavity.

Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must be able to sense and respond to changes in the environment. In this study, we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the activity of its type IV pili to sense the mechanical activity of the surface on which it is growing. This sensing mechanism is important for the pathogen because it allows it to regulate the activity of its type IV pili, which are important for surface attachment and virulence. This is an example of a mechanochemical model, where the mechanical activity of the cell is sensed and used to regulate the activity of the cell.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the past decades. However, the impact of pesticides on the environment is still poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation, which reveals that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on the world, and the discovery of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living animals has raised concerns about the potential for spillback into the human population. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer, and the discovery of multiple human lineages in deer. Our findings suggest that SARS-CoV-2 is circulating in deer, and that multiple human-to-deer transmission events have occurred. These discoveries have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic, and highlight the need for a robust and proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major problem that is not being addressed. The paper examines the problems and proposes solutions.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) peptide is the primary component of the plaques that are the hallmark of the disease. However, the role of Aβ in the immune response in AD is not well understood. Here, we show that neurons, which are the main cell type in the brain, are capable of producing a variety of immune factors, including cytokines, in response to Aβ. We also show that the extent of the immune response in neurons correlates with the extent of microgliosis, which is a critical component of the AD pathology. Finally, we demonstrate that the Aβ-burdened neuron is a primary source of the inflammatory response in the brain, which may precede the formation of the insoluble Aβ plaques. These findings have important implications for the development of new therapeutic strategies for AD.

The domestication of the chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is one of the most important events in human history. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation remains elusive. Here we present a comprehensive survey of the chicken remains from 234 archaeological sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia. Our results show that the frequency of chicken bones in the Southern Levant increased sharply during the Hellenistic period, and that the earliest secure evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe predates the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The folding of a protein is a complex process, and the details are not known for most proteins. However, the folding of a few proteins has been studied in great detail, and the results can be used to infer the general folding process. This paper describes the folding of one of the best studied proteins, the maltose binding protein. The results are important because they show that the folding of a large protein can be divided into distinct steps, and that the steps are not random but are ordered. The results are also important because they show that the steps are not irreversible but can be reversed by unfolding the protein. This is a significant finding because it suggests that the steps are reversible, and that the protein can be unfolded and refolded. The results are also important because they show that the steps are not the same for all proteins but depend on the protein. These results are important because they suggest that the steps are not unique to the proteins studied but are common to all proteins. (Show more)

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. However, the mechanism by which this occurs is not well understood. Here, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing the cap from Np4-capped RNAs is also capable of removing the cap from transcripts that are not capped with Np4. This finding has implications for the regulation of gene expression during stress, as well as for the development of new antibacterial strategies.

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with a high mortality rate. Although the mechanisms involved in the development of sepsis are not fully understood, it is clear that the immune system is involved in the pathogenesis of the disease. In this study, we demonstrate that arginine, a key amino acid in the urea cycle, is a key molecule in the regulation of the immune system during sepsis. Our results suggest that arginine supplementation could be a promising strategy for the treatment of sepsis.

The biomass of the biosphere is a key quantity for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. Our analysis reveals that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. This work is a step toward a global census of the biomass of all taxa. View Full-Text

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a fascinating phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system evolves in time in a way that the rate of change is proportional to the energy density. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a tropical model with self-organized criticality (SOC) behavior. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, electronics, and quantum applications. However, its properties are limited by its small bandgap, which is only 5.6 eV. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, with a fully closed bandgap, by applying tensile strain. We also show that diamond can be demetallized by applying compressive strain. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. Our findings are also important for understanding the physics of metallization and demetallization in diamond. Our findings are also important for understanding the physics of metallization and demetallization in diamond.

The study of the structure and function of peptides is of great interest to the scientific community and the pharmaceutical industry. However, the study of peptides is often hampered by the lack of structural information. Here, we report the solution structure of a unique antifungal peptide, NCR044, and its mode of action against plant fungal pathogens. The structure of the peptide is largely disordered and dynamic, and it exhibits potent antifungal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens. This work provides a structural basis for the antifungal activity of the peptide and paves the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This work also provides a structural basis for the antifungal activity of the peptide and paves the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome. We show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm is dynamic after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the proteome of the female reproductive tract is dynamic after mating. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, where it is essential for the formation of a platelet plug. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that the A1 domain in VWF is capable of switching between two states, one of which is more sensitive to flow. This mechanism explains the pathophysiology of VWD, and may also be relevant to other disorders of platelet function.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem that has been the focus of intense study for the past decade. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been more difficult to study, in part because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive database for human-associated viruses, which will enable the study of the impact of viruses on human health.

Progress on understanding ACI processes is hampered by inadequate observational capability. This study introduces a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to simultaneously measure aerosol and cloud properties. The technique is verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques. A case study over Beijing highlights the scientific potential of the technique to contribute to the understanding of ACI. The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of great interest for many years. The temperature of the surface of the Earth is important for understanding the evolution of life on the planet. The temperature of the Earth’s surface has been inferred from isotopic data, but the accuracy of these estimates has been questioned. We present a method for determining the temperature of the Earth’s surface based on the thermostability of enzymes.

Ion channels are the main ion-conducting proteins in cells and are responsible for the regulation of ion flow. The two pore-gate K+ channels, which are the most common type of ion channels, have two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. We found that the BK channel’s activation/deactivation and C-type inactivation/recovery are state-dependent and that C-type inactivation in the BK channel is closed state-dependent. We propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. Our findings provide a new perspective on the regulation of ion channels. Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with 207 million cases and 627,000 deaths in 2015. The parasite, Plasmodium, uses a variety of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell (RBC) and cause disease. Here, we show that the malaria parasite uses a single protein, erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175), to bind to glycophorin A (GPA) on the RBC surface. We show that this interaction alters the biophysical properties of the RBC, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This is a major change in our understanding of malaria invasion, suggesting that the parasite and host cell are working together to facilitate entry. This work provides a new perspective on the malaria invasion process and opens up a number of exciting avenues for future research. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, electronics, and quantum applications. However, its electronic properties are still not fully understood. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under mechanical strain, and the bandgap can be tuned by strain. Our findings provide a new route to tailor the electronic properties of diamond. This work also provides a platform for machine learning of the electronic and phonon structures of diamond. This work is expected to be useful for the development of diamond-based devices. This work is expected to be useful for the development of diamond-based devices.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. Despite the availability of effective vaccines and antiviral drugs, the disease continues to cause significant burden to human health. In this study, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity increases susceptibility to severe influenza virus infection. We further show that this increase in susceptibility is due to impaired host defense against influenza infection, reduced tissue repair, and caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our study provides insights into the mechanisms of disease pathogenesis and may lead to the development of new strategies for the prevention and treatment of influenza virus infection. (Show more)

The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and phrases at the branches. However, the neurophysiological evidence for this structure is limited. Here, we show that the brain’s activity during the processing of sentences is consistent with a model in which each word is merged into a phrase, and that this merge operation is applied equally to words and phrases. Our results suggest that the brain uses a bottom-up parser to build a hierarchy of nested phrases from the incoming language stream. This parser may be a fundamental feature of the brain’s processing of language.

Axin is a key component of the Wnt signaling pathway, which is involved in a wide range of biological processes, including cell fate determination, cell proliferation, and cell differentiation. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates, Axin1 and Axin2, are regulated differently at the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation confers tissue-specific regulation of the two forms of Axin, which is important for the proper functioning of the Wnt signaling pathway.

The brain circuit that promotes overeating is not well understood. Here we present a characterization of the brain circuit that promotes overeating in mice. We show that electrical stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus induces eating in sated mice, and that this effect is blocked by lesions of the lateral hypothalamus or dopamine. We also show that the dopamine system is not required for this effect. Finally, we show that stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus promotes eating in mice in a dopamine-dependent manner.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and bacteria is a key technology for sustainable agriculture. Here, we demonstrate the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also provides a proof of principle for the use of rhizopine as a synthetic signal for this purpose. This technology has the potential to revolutionize agriculture and is a key step toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis. (Show more)

We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their bodies to sense the world around them, but some animals, such as spiders, can sense the world without a body. This is because they can sense the world through their webs. This study shows that spiders can sense the world through their webs, and that the webs are the ears of the spider.

We estimate the climate and health benefits of a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources. We find that a phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources can save 3.61 million lives per year, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to have a devastating impact on the global community. The development of vaccines is a critical step in the fight against the pandemic. Here we report the design and characterization of a recombinant protein vaccine candidate that can be produced at large scale, with the potential to provide a cost-effective solution for the global community.

The role of ALK in the development of human cancer has been established by the discovery of ALK mutations in neuroblastoma. In this study, we show that zebrafish ALK/Ltk signaling is activated by ALKALs, a finding that is supported by biochemical and in vitro assays. We further show that ALKALs are required for the development of iridophores, a neural crest-derived tissue. Our results provide evidence for a role of ALK/Ltk signaling in the development of iridophores and other neural crest-derived tissues. This study provides a basis for further investigations of the role of ALK/Ltk signaling in the development of neural crest-derived tissues.

The emergence of plague, a disease that has plagued humanity for millennia, is a complex story that has been difficult to reconstruct due to the lack of ancient DNA evidence. Here, we present 17 Yersinia pestis genomes from the Late Neolithic and Early Bronze Age period, which is a critical period in the development of the disease. Our results reveal a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents. These data provide insights into the early evolution of plague and its ecology. They also reveal the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in the Caucasus and the Volga regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years. (Show more)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—and their support for Donald Trump. We found that HM predicted men’s and women’s support for Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. HM was also associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia. These findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. The agricultural management of grasslands and cropland has been shown to have a large impact on the amount of carbon (C) stored in the soil. However, the effects of different management practices on the distribution of C in the soil are not well understood. We show that the management of a long-term field experiment in the United States has led to a significant increase in the amount of carbon stored in the soil, with the greatest increases occurring in pastures and the smallest increases occurring in cropland. These results highlight the importance of well-managed grasslands in the fight against climate change.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize the highest-risk viruses, which can be used to inform research and public health interventions. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The SpillOver platform is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that SpillOver will be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to animals for pollination. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts pollinators, but the mechanisms that underlie the production of nectar pigments are poorly understood. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify the enzymes responsible for the production of this pigment in the nectar of N. mauritianus and two distantly related hummingbird-visited species. Our findings provide insight into the evolution of this trait and the mechanisms that underlie the production of nectar pigments. This work also demonstrates that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. (Show more)

The genetic history of Europe during the Early Medieval period is poorly understood. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who lived mostly between the 5th and 7th centuries AD. We find that the genetic ancestry of the men is mostly consistent with modern northern and central Europeans, but that the genetic ancestries of the women are very heterogeneous, including signals of genetic ancestry from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we find that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. Our results suggest that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a newly emerged pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results suggest that MERS-CoV, but not HKU4, has adapted to use human cells for cross-species transmission. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells. (Show more)

The ability to rapidly identify the cause of undifferentiated febrile illness is critical to the early detection and response to emerging and reemerging infectious diseases. We used a global cloud-based platform to perform unbiased metagenomic sequencing of RNA extracted from serum samples of febrile patients in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya virus, which presaged a national outbreak. Our results highlight the potential of mNGS to provide a rapid and cost-effective approach to pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings. This approach can be used to identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. The results of this study have implications for the global response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) is responsible for replicating the lagging strand template in eukaryotes. The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. In this study, we developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the pol δ holoenzyme is not stable on undamaged DNA and that the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is lost in humans. These results have profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. Our results suggest that the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is a key determinant of the fidelity of lagging strand replication. (Show more)

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in biology. In the RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules. In vitro evolution of RNA molecules has led to the discovery of a variety of RNA molecules that can replicate themselves. Here, we report the development of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can synthesize a variety of functional RNA molecules, including aptamers, ribozymes, and tRNA. This RNA polymerase ribozyme can replicate RNA, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of the PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work represents a significant step toward the realization of the RNA world.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

The clinical characteristics of COVID-19 are still unclear, and the treatment is still in the process of exploration. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which is effective in treating rheumatoid arthritis, may be effective in treating COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal that can cause damage to cells. The ability of fungi to sequester copper in the form of isocyanide-derived compounds is described here. The copper-binding properties of these compounds are demonstrated, and the impact of copper homeostasis on fungal physiology is discussed. The existence of the xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster in several filamentous fungi suggests a role for these compounds in the regulation of copper homeostasis and the ability of fungi to compete with other microbes for copper. This work provides insight into the role of fungal natural products in copper homeostasis and the ability of fungi to compete with other microbes for essential metals. (Show more)

The discovery of tridymite in a sedimentary rock in Gale crater, Mars, is significant because it is a high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of SiO2, a mineral that is not stable at the temperatures and pressures of the present-day crust and surface of Mars. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary rock in a crater interior suggests that the rock was formed at a depth where the temperature and pressure conditions are more similar to those of the Earth’s mantle.

Frost is a major environmental factor that limits the distribution of plants and animals in the Northern Hemisphere. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is changing, and that the resistance strategies of trees are not adapted to the new conditions. Our findings have important implications for land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the mechanisms by which Th17 cells contribute to disease are not well understood. Here we show that Th17 cells can contribute to the development of classic Th1 cells and that this process requires the expression of the transcription factor T-bet. These findings have implications for the development of new therapies for inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is difficult to model in animal models, and there are no effective treatments. We now report a method to convert human fibroblasts from living ALS patients into induced astrocytes. This method enables rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to identify treatments for ALS. This method will be useful for ALS research and drug discovery. It will also be useful for other neurodegenerative diseases, as well as for other cell types. This method will be useful for ALS research and drug discovery. It will also be useful for other neurodegenerative diseases, as well as for other cell types. (Show more)

The gut microbiota of ticks is a complex community that is important for the health of the tick and the pathogen it harbors. In this study, we show that the tick antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp) is a bacterial growth inhibitor that is expressed in response to Anaplasma phagocytophilum infection. IAFGP binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings provide insight into the mechanisms by which a human pathogen exploits an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This knowledge may be useful for the development of new strategies to control vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

Birds are a highly diverse group of animals, and the study of their evolution has been a major focus of paleontology for the past century. However, the study of the origin of the modern avian body plan has been complicated by the lack of fossils from the earliest diverging lineages. Here, we describe a new species of early bird from the Early Cretaceous of China, which adds to our understanding of the origin of the modern avian body plan.

We show that the water vapor in the stratosphere plays an important role in the climate system. This is because the water vapor in the stratosphere is not in equilibrium with the temperature, as it is in the troposphere. This means that the water vapor in the stratosphere increases with temperature, and that this increase is a feedback to the climate system.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, due to the presence of pigments in their tissues. However, some vertebrates have blue-green tissues, a phenomenon called chlorosis. The biochemical basis of chlorosis is poorly understood, and the evolutionary history of this phenomenon is unknown. Here, we show that the occurrence of high biliverdin in anurans has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and that this is due to the presence of a class of proteins that bind biliverdin. We also describe a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. Our results present molecular and functional evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily. This study provides a molecular and functional perspective on the evolution of chlorosis. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a feature of many cancers, and is associated with the maintenance of cancer stem cells, which are responsible for tumor initiation and recurrence. We report that hypoxia induces expression of the m6A demethylase, AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which in turn increases the expression of the pluripotency factor NANOG, and that this effect is mediated by hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF)-dependent expression of ALKBH5. This study provides insight into the role of ALKBH5 in cancer, and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for breast cancer. (Show more)

The Bible is one of the most important books in the world. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century, and the source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy. This paper reports the results of a study of 465 parchment samples, including 72 pocket Bibles, using a simple and objective method that identifies the animal origin of the parchment. The results suggest that the source of the parchment was not limited to abortive or newborn animals.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. The age model for the extinction is critical to understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present new U-Pb zircon dates from the Global Stratotype Section and Point for the Permian-Triassic boundary at Meishan, China, that define an age model for the extinction and allow exploration of the links between global environmental perturbation, carbon cycle disruption, mass extinction, and recovery at millennial timescales. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle was highly volatile during the extinction and recovery, and the trigger and kill hypotheses are unlikely to be valid. (Show more)

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a group of chronic inflammatory diseases of the gastrointestinal tract, which is characterized by the presence of inflammation in the intestinal mucosa. IBD is a complex disease, and the exact pathogenesis is still unknown. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) plays an important role in the intestinal inflammation of IBD. We also found that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses. Our study provides a potential therapeutic target for IBD. This study also provides a new direction for the treatment of IBD. (Show more)

The spike protein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. The D614G mutation is the most common substitution in circulating variants, and it is thought to increase the infectivity of the virus. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the D614G and G614 spikes and show that the G614 mutant spike is more open and may facilitate binding to the receptor. These results may help to explain the increased infectivity of variants with the D614G mutation. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.
