COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that, in the absence of the pandemic, life expectancy at birth would have been 78.65 y in 2020, a decline of 1.13 y, the lowest since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry, and they are the starting point for the development of chemical models. In this paper, we show that the chemical properties of atoms change with pressure, and we propose a new way of thinking about the chemical properties of atoms.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and intensity of fire, but the effects of fire on climate are poorly understood. We show that changes in fire activity, driven by climate, socioeconomic, and demographic changes, can have a significant impact on the global carbon cycle. We find that changes in fire activity have acted to warm climate throughout most of the 20th century, but recent and predicted future reductions in fire activity may reverse this, enhancing land carbon uptake and corresponding to offsetting ∼5 to 10 y of global CO2 emissions at today’s levels. Our study highlights the importance of fire in driving future fire regimes and the need to understand the feedbacks between fire and climate change.

The delivery of nutrients to symbiotic microorganisms is a well-known mechanism for regulating the stability of the mutualism between host and symbiont. However, the mechanisms by which the host delivers nutrients to the symbionts, and the consequences of such delivery, are not well understood. Here, we show that the delivery of a single glycan to the symbiotic organ of the squid Euprymna scolopes is critical for the maintenance of the symbiont population and for the production of bioluminescence at night. This glycan is provided by the host only at night, and its catabolism is required for the acidification of the symbiotic organ, which enhances the activity of the symbionts. We propose that this strategy is used by other hosts to control the activities of their symbionts. (Show more)

Text data are ubiquitous, but the patterns that they reveal are often difficult to identify. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data, which we call discourse atom topic modeling (DATM). We use a generative model to identify a set of latent topics that are distributed over words in a text. We also identify a set of discourse atoms that are distributed over topics in a space of topics. Our method is flexible and can be applied to a wide range of domains. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. We believe that our method will be useful to researchers in many fields.

The second plague pandemic, which started in the Mediterranean in the 14th century, is generally considered to have been caused by a single introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease spread over four centuries in Europe. We show that this pandemic was the consequence of repeated introductions of the bacterium into European harbors, which were caused by climate-driven changes in the distribution of rodents. Our results suggest that the Black Death was the result of multiple introductions of Y. pestis, which were separated by long periods of time, and that the disease was not established in Europe until the end of the 14th century.

Asteroids are a major component of the marine ecosystem, and their loss has a significant impact on the ecosystem. We show that a densovirus is the most likely cause of the mass mortality of sea stars (asteroid species) in the Northeast Pacific.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia in adults, and the prognosis is poor. The identification of targets for therapy is therefore of great importance. In this study, we show that the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is a promising target for therapy of AML. We show that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We also show that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Finally, we demonstrate that an antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling can be used to treat AML. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This study also provides a proof of principle for the use of antibodies as a treatment for AML. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, we found that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. Our results provide insights into the settlement history of Madagascar and the genetic consequences of the island’s unique geography. They also provide a framework for the study of human diversity in the Indian Ocean. (Show more)

Bacteria are able to sense and respond to a variety of environmental cues. One of the most important cues is the availability of carbon sources. In this study, we describe a small RNA that is able to modulate the expression of genes involved in the utilization of carbon sources.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our work has the potential to accelerate the development of new therapeutics to combat the COVID-19 pandemic.

Crop experts are the eyes and ears of the agricultural community, and their knowledge is critical to monitor crop status and predict crop yields. However, the information they provide is often qualitative and subjective, and is not easily integrated into quantitative models. We show that the Crop Progress and Condition (CPC) survey, which is the primary source of information on crop status in the US, is a rich source of information that can be used to build a quantitative model of crop status. We show that the CPC data can be transformed into a continuous probabilistic variable that is robust to changes in the survey design, and can be used to monitor crop status and predict crop yields. Our results show that the CPC data can be used to provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our approach can be easily extended to other crops and countries.

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in neuronal excitability that occur during learning. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the duration of memory. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the duration of memory. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community and the general public. However, despite considerable scientific attention in recent decades, the overall response of soil respiration to anticipated climatic warming remains unclear. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important evolutionary events in the history of life. It is also one of the most difficult to study, because it is difficult to observe the process in real time. We present a model of the molecular evolution of the plastid genome during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition is not a single event, but rather a gradual process, in which the selection pressure on the plastid genome is relaxed in a stepwise manner. Our findings have implications for the study of the molecular evolution of the plastid genome, as well as for the study of the evolution of the parasitic lifestyle.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark example of the impact of climate change on water resources in South Africa. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in the region. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5 [SSP2-4.5]) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. (Show more)

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has been a major advance in the field of materials science. However, the conditions under which they are formed are not understood. Here, we report the discovery of a new quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this new quasicrystal, Si61Cu30Ca7Fe2, is significant because it is the oldest known anthropogenic quasicrystal, and because it was formed under conditions that are similar to those under which naturally occurring quasicrystals form. This discovery has implications for the search for new quasicrystal-forming systems. (Show more)

Photosynthesis is the basis of life on Earth. The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophylls is one of the most productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key feature of (bacterio)chlorophylls, has remained a mystery for more than 60 y. This paper describes the evolution of the enzymes that catalyze this reaction, and their role in the biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophylls.

Neuroinflammation is a major feature of many neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is also a major feature of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), a model of MS. Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) ASK1, which is known to be involved in neuroinflammation. However, the precise roles of ASK1 in neuroinflammation remain unknown. Here, we show that ASK1 is required for neuroinflammation in microglia/macrophages and astrocytes, but not in T cells and dendritic cells. Our findings suggest that ASK1 is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study also provides a better understanding of the roles of glial cells in EAE pathophysiology. (Show more)

California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. We show that the probability of co-occurring warm and dry conditions has increased in recent decades, and that this increase is almost entirely due to human activities.

Autism is a complex disorder with a variety of symptoms, and the etiology is not yet fully understood. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our study provides a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral inflexibility observed in autism and may facilitate the development of new treatments. (Show more)
This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content.

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ homeostasis, and mutations in the proteins that form the channel pore or the Ca2+ sensor that regulates channel activity result in severe immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify mutations in two of the proteins that form the CRAC channel that result in a spectrum of hematological and skeletal muscle abnormalities, including congenital miosis and myopathy, and suggest new therapeutic approaches for patients with Stormorken syndrome. Our findings expand our understanding of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapeutic approaches for patients with Stormorken syndrome and related conditions. (Show more)

The study of the spread of disease-causing proteins in the brain is a major focus of research in neurodegenerative diseases. Here we show that the spread of polyglutamine-expanded huntingtin in Drosophila is non–cell-autonomous, and that this spreading causes the death of vulnerable neurons. We also show that the spread of aggregates requires the fusion of vesicles, and that the release of aggregates is dependent on the activity of the fusion protein. These results provide a model for the spread of disease-causing proteins in the brain, and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

The role of bats in the emergence of zoonotic diseases is a major concern in the scientific community. However, the factors that contribute to the emergence of viruses from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of bats and demonstrated that this protein is a potent immunomodulator that inhibits the antiviral immune response of the host and facilitates viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of bats in the emergence of zoonotic diseases. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of cell growth, and thus requires the one-carbon unit derived from the folate cycle. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), which is up-regulated in cancer. We show that this inhibitor is effective in vitro and in vivo, and that it is particularly effective in B-cell lines. We also show that the one-carbon donor formate is a rescue for SHMT inhibition in cancer cells, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in a DLBCL cell line. These studies identify a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. This work provides a foundation for the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics. (Show more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form intracellular inclusion bodies that are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This metastable state is likely a consequence of the unique cellular environment of the motor neuron, and may be a common feature of neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The photonic crystals are designed to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. The device can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The device can be used to study a variety of phenomena, including the role of the photonic band structure in atom–light interactions, the role of the atomic array in atom–atom interactions, and the role of the photonic crystal in the control of spontaneous emission. The device can also be used to study the role of the atomic array in the control of spontaneous emission. The origin of the flowering plants is a major topic in plant science. The study of Montsechia, a plant from the Cretaceous, has led to a new understanding of the origin of the flowering plants.

The study of ancient viruses is hampered by the lack of ancient viral DNA in the archaeological record. Here we present the first ancient human viruses, which were recovered from dental and skeletal remains of individuals who lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event that formed the most common B19V genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

Sea level is a key indicator of climate change because it is sensitive to both ocean mass and water density. We find that the acceleration of global mean sea level over the last 25 y is best fit by a quadratic in time, indicating that the acceleration is increasing in magnitude. This implies that global mean sea level could rise 65 cm by 2100 compared with 2005, roughly in agreement with the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) 5th Assessment Report (AR5) model projections.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, each successive birth cohort has a higher prevalence of pain at each age—a result not found for those with a bachelor’s degree. This pattern is consistent with the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If these patterns continue, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults; tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. The application of NMR-assisted crystallography to the study of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate provides a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of structure and reactivity that is key to understanding the reaction pathway and the role of the active site in catalysis.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe pneumonia caused by a coronavirus that emerged in 2012. The disease has a high case fatality rate, and there is no specific treatment. We tested the efficacy of remdesivir, a drug that has been shown to inhibit SARS-CoV replication in vitro, in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection. Prophylactic treatment with remdesivir completely prevented the development of clinical disease, and therapeutic treatment reduced the severity of disease, the viral load in the lungs, and the extent of lung damage. These results support the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial of MERS-CoV infection. The drug may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV.

The delivery of nutrients to symbiotic microorganisms is a well-known mechanism by which hosts control the activities of their microbial partners. However, the mechanisms by which hosts regulate the activities of these microorganisms are not well understood. Here, we show that the delivery of a single glycan to a symbiotic bacterium is sufficient to control the activities of the symbiont and the host organ. This glycan is provided by the host, in a specific manner, at a specific time of day, and is required for the host’s ability to maintain a healthy symbiont population. This glycan is also required for the host’s ability to maintain a healthy organ. We propose that this glycan delivery is a general mechanism by which hosts control the activities of their symbionts.

This study shows that it is possible to reduce suspension rates in middle schools. The study also shows that it is possible to change teachers’ mindsets about discipline. This is a major contribution to the field, as it shows that it is possible to change the way teachers think about students and their behavior.

DNA alkylation is one of the major causes of DNA damage and is a major contributor to the development of cancer and other diseases. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the impact of O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (EtdT) lesions on the transcriptional fidelity checkpoints and transcriptional lesion bypass routes. We found that the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Taken together, this work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. To better understand the mechanisms of MERS-CoV infection, we engineered viruses with mutations that blocked sequential proteolysis of the virus spike (S) glycoprotein. We found that these mutations compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into other cell types. These findings suggest that sequential proteolysis is a determinant of MERS-CoV tropism, and that the first cleavages are significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is a major contributor to environmental degradation and is a leading cause of biodiversity loss and climate change. The food choices of the majority of people in high-income countries have a significant impact on the environment and on their own health. We show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can lead to a proportional increase in vegetarian meal sales of 61.8% and 40.8% in two observational studies and 78.8% in an experimental study. These results provide robust evidence to support the potential for simple changes to catering practices to make an important contribution to achieving more sustainable diets at the population level.

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for the cell to interact with the extracellular space. We have developed a method to study the surfaceome of cancer cells, and applied it to six different oncogenes. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a significant step forward in our understanding of cancer cell surface biology and the development of new cancer therapies.

In the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the molecular basis of the disease. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which reveals a unique mechanism of immune evasion.

Hypoxia is a common condition in the human body, and it is also a major factor in the pathogenesis of cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia are not well understood. Here we show that hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats, and that this is associated with the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1. This leads to an increase in the expression of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) in astrocytes, which is associated with an increase in water influx into the brain, and edema. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms underlying the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia. They also suggest a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of cerebral edema in hypoxia. (Show more)

The world is full of associations. We are interested in the ones that are important, but we don’t want to be misled by associations that are just random noise. We need a way to assess the strength of an association. This paper describes a way to do this, and illustrates it with three examples: forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis.

The development of vascular ECs is a complex process that requires the coordinated expression of multiple transcription factors. However, the minimum number of transcription factors that are required for the direct conversion of nonvascular cells into ECs is unknown. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) is the most important transcription factor for the direct conversion of human fibroblasts into ECs. Furthermore, ETV2-mediated conversion of human fibroblasts into ECs is associated with the expression of multiple endothelial development factors, including FLI1, ERG, and TAL1. In addition, ETV2-mediated conversion of human fibroblasts into ECs is associated with the formation of mature functional vasculature in vivo. Our study provides a new strategy for the generation of ECs and the development of vascular networks. This strategy may be applicable to the treatment of vascular disorders. (Show more)

The discovery of the ligand for anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) has led to the development of a new class of targeted therapies for ALK-driven cancers. However, the role of ALK in normal development has been controversial. Here, we show that ALK ligands are also important for the development of zebrafish iridophores, which are responsible for the coloration of the eye and the body. We also show that ALK ligands are important for the development of iridophores in the eye and the body. These findings establish a physiological link between ALK ligands and ALK and demonstrate that ALK ligands are important for the development of iridophores in the eye and the body. This work provides a foundation for future studies of the role of ALK ligands in normal development. (Show more)

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. Although insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction are two main molecular bases for T2D, the molecular mechanisms underlying their interaction are not fully understood. Herein, we found that STING, a key molecule in the interferon (IFN) pathway, plays an important role in the regulation of insulin sensitivity and β-cell function. We also found that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING deficiency in β-cells impaired GSIS, indicating that STING is required for normal β-cell function. These findings provide insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying the interaction between insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction, which may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. The genome of the virus is segmented into eight fragments, which is an evolutionary advantage but complicates the packaging of the genome into the viral particles. Here, we identified a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion. We also demonstrated that this mechanism is required for optimal viral replication. Our results indicate that the packaging of the viral genome is a sequence-dependent process, in which the viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome. The lack of conservation of this mechanism among influenza A viruses might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is the leading cause of death worldwide. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a complex process that is regulated by a variety of factors. The role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in mediating the mechanotransduction and vascular homeostasis has been well established. However, the role of YAP/TAZ in the regulation of atheroprone phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions has not been investigated. In this study, we found that the activation of YAP/TAZ by disturbed flow is critical for the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesions. Our study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of atherosclerosis. (Show more)

Wildfire is a natural process that has been a part of the Earth system for millennia. However, in the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. We show that human activities have greatly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire, and that the majority of these fires are started intentionally. We recommend that the United States focus on reducing the risk of human-caused wildfires to reduce the costs of wildfire and to protect the lives and property of the growing population in fire-prone areas.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a class of plant-derived compounds that are used to protect humans and animals from insect bites. However, the molecular targets of natural repellents in arthropods are still unknown. Here, we identified a scorpion TRP channel that mediates the avoidance behavior of natural repellents. This study provides a new perspective on the molecular targets of natural repellents in arthropods, and may help in the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help in understanding the evolution of plant–arthropod interaction. (Show more)

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the role of the immune system in the pathogenesis of the disease is well established. Here we present a mathematical model of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We estimate the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques, and we assess the effect of an antiviral treatment on the time to undetectable plasma viral load. Our results provide insights into the mechanisms of disease and can be used to guide the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Coral reefs are among the most valuable ecosystems on Earth, but they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors. In particular, the increasing frequency of heat stress events is causing widespread bleaching and the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis. We show that the breakdown of the symbiosis is preceded by a shift in the metabolic behavior of the coral host, which is driven by altered nutrient cycling. This shift is a consequence of the increased energy demand of the coral host, which is met by the degradation of amino acids. The resulting shift in nutrient cycling promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. Together, these processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. (Show more)

The intestinal epithelium is a critical barrier that protects the organism from the environment. In the case of cancer, the epithelium becomes defective, leading to the loss of barrier function and the entry of the tumor cells into the systemic circulation. Here, we show that the intestinal microbiome can regulate the activity of the epithelium, and that the loss of the microbiome can lead to the activation of a tumor-promoting loop. Our work identifies a mechanism that can be targeted to control the activity of the epithelium and prevent the entry of tumor cells into the systemic circulation. It also highlights the importance of maintaining the integrity of the intestinal epithelium to prevent the development of cancer. (Show more)

Chemotherapy is the mainstay of treatment for patients with breast cancer, but the response to treatment is variable. In this study, we show that the expression of the orphan receptor tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 is up-regulated in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also show that ROR1 is a therapeutic target that can be used to improve the response to chemotherapy in mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may be a promising strategy for improving the response to chemotherapy in patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The start of deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is often attributed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, but this is not supported by paleoclimate records. We show that a series of volcanic eruptions, coincident with the start of deglaciation, led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a climate response that was similar to that observed today. This finding has important implications for the interpretation of past climate change and the role of stratospheric ozone depletion in the climate system. (Show more)

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. Our analysis also shows that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, highlighting the importance of inland fisheries in regions where food security is low. Our data can be used to identify the locations of productive fisheries and the populations that depend on them, and can be used to prioritize conservation efforts in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors. This analysis can help to ensure that the importance of freshwater fisheries is recognized in environmental planning and management.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable character of the material is the key to achieve high energy density and long cycle life. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work provides a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy devices. This work is expected to be a milestone in the field of energy storage.

The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, neurons are largely incapable of regenerating after injury. Here, we identify a form of regeneration in C. elegans that is independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to be required for regeneration in many other species. Our study reveals a previously unknown form of regeneration in the nervous system, which may be a powerful platform for discovery of factors that control the intrinsic regenerative capacity of the nervous system.

The process of recombination is fundamental to the evolution of genomes and the diversity of life. However, the spatial and temporal patterns of recombination in plants, which are the dominant form of life on land, are poorly understood. Here, we present a detailed map of recombination in a flowering plant, the monkeyflower Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination is highly variable across the genome, with some regions of the genome showing no detectable recombination. We also find that recombination is more likely to occur at the start of genes than in the middle or end of genes. These results provide a foundation for understanding the evolution of recombination in plants. They also provide a resource for future studies of the genetics of flowering plants.

The study of the brain’s functional architecture is a major challenge in neuroscience. Here, we used a nonfluctuating imaging modality, positron emission tomography, to identify and validate the resting state organization of the human brain. We found that the dominant metabolic RSN in healthy subjects was topographically similar to the DMN. In contrast, in PD, this RSN was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. We found that the dominant RSN was deactivated during task performance, and that this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. Time-course comparisons of DMN loss in longitudinal resting metabolic scans from PD and Alzheimer’s disease subjects illustrated that significant reductions appeared later for PD, in parallel with the development of cognitive dysfunction. In contrast, in Alzheimer’s disease significant reductions in network expression were already present at diagnosis, progressing over time. Our results provide a new perspective on the organization of the brain’s functional architecture.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. We report the discovery of a second 5′ modification in eukaryotes, a 5′ nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) cap. We also report the discovery of a second class of 5′ modification in yeast, a 5′ NAD+ cap that is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs.

The study of epigenetic mechanisms has led to the discovery of the role of DNA methylation in the regulation of gene expression. In this study, we show that DNA methylation patterns at specific loci in blood cells are different in people with diabetes compared with controls, and that these differences persist over time. These findings support the hypothesis that epigenetic mechanisms are involved in the maintenance of metabolic memory. This work may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of diabetes.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer, and the lack of effective treatment options has led to a high mortality rate. We show that the expression of a cancer antigen, FSIP1, is associated with poor prognosis in TNBC patients. FSIP1 deficiency in TNBC cells leads to autophagy induction, AMPK activation, and inhibition of mTOR and Wnt/β-catenin signaling. These findings may aid in the design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a complex disorder that is difficult to treat. The present study shows that the gut microbiota is altered in alcohol-dependent subjects and that some of them develop gut leakiness, which is associated with psychological symptoms of the disease. These results suggest that the gut microbiota may be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The production of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit is essential for the development of a distinctive aroma, but the biosynthetic pathways for these compounds are not known. Here we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase, which catalyzes sequential hydroxylation reactions to produce the final products. This work provides a major advance in our understanding of the biosynthesis of these compounds and will be a useful resource for the development of new cultivars with improved flavor. (Show more)

Biodiversity is a key component of ecosystem functioning, but the effects of global warming on this relationship are poorly understood. We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature, and that this sensitivity is driven by changes in the thermal tolerance of species. Our results highlight the importance of considering the effects of global warming in combination with biodiversity loss, and suggest that the additional impacts of warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation, and its neurons are organized into distinct cell types that are thought to be specialized for different aspects of space. However, the anatomical organization of these cell types is not well understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice, and we found that grid cells, which are thought to be specialized for space, are not strongly segregated from other cell types. Instead, grid cells are strongly coupled among themselves and have weaker links to other cell types. These results suggest that the organization of MEC cell types is more complex than previously thought. They also provide a model for future studies of the organization of the brain. (Show more)

Flowering is a complex process, which is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the FT gene in the rootless dodder Cuscuta australis is not required for flowering of the host plant. Instead, we found that the FT protein is able to move from the host to the dodder, where it interacts with a dodder transcription factor to induce flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

The dopamine system of the brain is critical to movement and motivation. Here, we describe a previously unrecognized system of specialized cell bodies and their projections that are critical to dopamine function.

We all know it when we feel it: When two people are connected, they “click.” But how do we know when two people “click”? We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we demonstrate that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, the sinoatrial (SA) cells, which are responsible for generating the heart rate. The SA cells are responsible for maintaining a normal heart rate, which is essential for maintaining blood pressure and blood flow. In this study, we show that the calcium sensor STIM1 is expressed in the specialized cardiomyocytes of the SAN and is required for the normal heart rate. Our findings have important implications for understanding the mechanisms that control heart rate and may lead to the development of new therapies for heart disease. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, but its function in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is associated with an increase in the accumulation of Si and the expression of genes involved in defense responses. These results suggest that Si and JA may interact in the defense response against insect herbivores. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is an enzyme involved in ether lipid metabolism. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the activation of macrophages, which is a key step in the resolution of inflammation. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids.

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in neuronal excitability that occur during learning. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the length of time that information is stored. We believe that this mechanism is a plausible substrate for memory in the brain.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge due to the presence of the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells. Here, we demonstrate that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver biomolecules to plants, and that the size, shape, and geometry of the DNA nanostructures are important for the delivery of biomolecules to plants. We also show that the delivery of biomolecules to plants is dependent on the attachment locus of the biomolecule, which is important for the endogenous gene silencing pathway. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is a significant step forward in the development of DNA nanostructures as a platform for the delivery of biomolecules to plants.

The coastal zone is a critical ecosystem that supports a wide range of valuable goods and services. However, coastal ecosystems are increasingly threatened by nutrient pollution, which is driven largely by nonpoint sources of nitrogen and phosphorus from surrounding watersheds. We show that the coastal zone is not a homogenous ecosystem, but rather is composed of a mosaic of nutrient inputs from small tributaries. Our findings suggest that small watersheds may be a significant source of coastal nutrient pollution, and that efforts to reduce nutrient loading in the coastal zone should focus on small tributaries.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is only available to a small fraction of the possible chemical states. We find that the dynamics of the system are biased toward states that are extremized with respect to the environmental forcing. We discuss the implications of this finding for the dynamics of complex networks of chemical reactions.

The mechanisms underlying the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in patients with autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Ab encephalitis is associated with changes in the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity. We then show that these changes are explained by changes in the dynamics of the cortical microcircuit. Finally, we show that these changes are associated with the development of overt paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. These findings offer mechanistic insights into the circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. They also suggest that the dynamics of the cortical microcircuit may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of these disorders.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key area of research in Earth system science. However, the history of C-rich events is poorly understood because of the difficulty in identifying them in the geological record. Here, we present a case study of an abrupt C-rich event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event can be linked to a global warming and anoxia of the deep ocean. Our results provide insights into the mechanisms that control the history of C-rich events and the potential for such events to occur in the future. (Show more)

The palm oil industry is the largest consumer of deforestation-prone tropical peatlands in the world. Despite the importance of peatlands for carbon storage, the industry has been expanding into these carbon-rich ecosystems at an alarming rate. We show that the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) certification program has had a positive impact on the conservation of peatlands in Indonesia. We find that RSPO certification has reduced the rate of forest loss in peatlands by 50%. However, certification has had no impact on active fire detection rates. Our results suggest that certification has not reduced the rate of forest loss in oil palm plantations, but it has reduced the rate of forest loss in peatlands.

The exocyst complex is a well-conserved protein complex that is involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. In this study, we discovered a small molecule that inhibits the exocytosis of plant cells and human cells. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental feature of animal biology, and the evolution of sex determination is a major topic of study. In this study, we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination alleles on secondary sexual characteristics in a species with polygenic sex determination. We find that the modularity of secondary sexual characteristics produced by polygenic sex determination provides context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. Our results highlight the importance of considering the effects of multiple alleles in the study of sex determination. (Show more)

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by the presence of reactive oxygen species and reactive carbonyl species. These species are generated by the metabolism of vitamin A and can damage the retina. We show that the presence of iron in the retina can promote the oxidation and degradation of these species. This work provides insight into the role of iron in the retina and may lead to the development of new therapies for retinal disease. (Show more)

Predators are the foundation of all food webs, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a central topic in ecology and evolution. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as it is difficult to evolve morphological and functional optimizations in separate structures. Here we show that this is not the case in the siphonophores, a group of pelagic cnidarians that use specialized side branches (tentacles) for prey capture. We show that siphonophore specialization is linked to the evolution of morphological and functional changes in the tentacles, and that shifts between prey types are linked to shifts in the morphology, mode of evolution, and evolutionary correlations of the tentacles. Our findings contribute to a broader understanding of the evolution of specialization in predators.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolution. The study of the human hand is complicated by the fact that the fossil record is incomplete, and that the hand is a complex system with many interacting components. We report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from East Africa that preserves the third metacarpal styloid process, a key derived feature of the modern human hand. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this feature and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This finding has implications for the evolution of the human hand and for the origins of modern human behavior. (Less)

Cancer is a disease of cell growth, and thus requires a constant supply of one-carbon units. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a key regulator of this supply. Here we report the discovery of a series of small-molecule inhibitors of SHMT, and show that they block colon cancer tumor growth in mice. We also show that one-carbon metabolism is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a disease in which the cancer cells are uniquely dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity to meet glycine demand. Thus, we have identified a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells that can be exploited therapeutically. This work represents a significant advance in the development of cancer therapeutics. (Show more)

The importance of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets is not well understood. This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables, which are important sources of vitamin A, and thus can lead to a reduction in vitamin A adequacy. Conversely, forest fragmentation can increase people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables, which can lead to an increase in vitamin A adequacy. These findings have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals.

The agricultural revolution has been accompanied by the development of farm machinery, which has greatly increased the capacity of agricultural production. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We hypothesize that the development of subsoil compaction is a recent phenomenon, and that the increase in vehicle weight has been the main driver of this trend.
